Keeps track of the gRPC connection state to know if timeout has been set or not.
gNMI version
Indicates if ASCII text of an out-of-band agreed format encoding is supported or not.
Indicates if arbitrarily encoded bytes encoding is supported or not.
Indicates if JSON encoded text is supported or not.
Indicates if JSON encoded text as per RFC7951 is supported or not.
Indicates if encoding according to scalar values of TypedValue is supported or not.
The system's current datetime when last polled.
The system's login banner.
The system's login banner.

This table gives an overview of the YANG models this data source supports.
This is the key used internally by DataMiner to identify the table entries.
Name of the model.
Version of the model.
Organization that defined the model.
Interfaces state table on change subscription.
The name of the interface.
The interface type.
Set the max transmission unit size in octets for the physical interface. If this is not set, the mtu is set to the operational default -- e.g., 1514 bytes on an Ethernet interface.
Loopback mode.
Description
State
Index
The desired state of the interface. In RFC 7223 this leaf has the same read semantics as ifAdminStatus. Here, it reflects the administrative state as set by enabling or disabling the interface.
The current operational state of the interface.

This timestamp indicates the absolute time of the last state change of the interface (e.g., up-to-down transition). This is different than the SNMP ifLastChange object in the standard interface MIB in that it is not relative to the system boot time (i.e,. sysUpTime).
The value is the timestamp in nanoseconds relative to the Unix Epoch (Jan 1, 1970 00:00:00 UTC).
When set to true, the interface is a logical interface which does not have an associated physical port or channel on the system.

The total number of octets received on the interface, including framing characters.
Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of 'last-clear'.
The total number of packets received on the interface, including all unicast, multicast, broadcast and bad packets etc.

The number of packets, delivered by this sub-layer to a higher (sub-)layer, that were not addressed to a multicast or broadcast address at this sub-layer.
Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of 'last-clear'.

The number of packets, delivered by this sub-layer to a higher (sub-)layer, that were addressed to a broadcast address at this sub-layer.
Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of 'last-clear'.

The number of packets, delivered by this sub-layer to a higher (sub-)layer, that were addressed to a multicast address at this sub-layer. For a MAC-layer protocol, this includes both Group and Functional addresses.
Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of 'last-clear'.

The number of inbound packets that were chosen to be discarded even though no errors had been detected to prevent their being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. One possible reason for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer space.
Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of 'last-clear'.

For packet-oriented interfaces, the number of inbound packets that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. For character- oriented or fixed-length interfaces, the number of inbound transmission units that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol.
Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of 'last-clear'.

For packet-oriented interfaces, the number of packets received via the interface that were discarded because of an unknown or unsupported protocol. For character-oriented or fixed-length interfaces that support protocol multiplexing, the number of transmission units received via the interface that were discarded because of an unknown or unsupported protocol. For any interface that does not support protocol multiplexing, this counter is not present.
Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of 'last-clear'.

Number of received packets which had errors in the frame check sequence (FCS), i.e., framing errors.
Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur when the device is re-initialization as indicated by the value of 'last-clear'.

The total number of octets transmitted out of the interface, including framing characters.
Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of 'last-clear'.
The total number of packets transmitted out of the interface, including all unicast, multicast, broadcast, and bad packets etc.

The number of packets, delivered by this sub-layer to a higher (sub-)layer, that were not addressed to a multicast or broadcast address at this sub-layer.
Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of 'last-clear'.

The total number of packets that higher-level protocols requested be transmitted, and that were addressed to a broadcast address at this sub-layer, including those that were discarded or not sent.
Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of 'last-clear'.

The total number of packets that higher-level protocols requested be transmitted, and that were addressed to a multicast address at this sub-layer, including those that were discarded or not sent. For a MAC-layer protocol, this includes both Group and Functional addresses.
Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of 'last-clear'.

The number of outbound packets that were chosen to be discarded even though no errors had been detected to prevent their being transmitted. One possible reason for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer space.
Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of 'last-clear'.

For packet-oriented interfaces, the number of outbound packets that could not be transmitted because of errors. For character-oriented or fixed-length interfaces, the number of outbound transmission units that could not be transmitted because of errors.
Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of 'last-clear'.
Number of times the interface state has transitioned between up and down since the time the device restarted or the last-clear time, whichever is most recent.

Timestamp of the last time the interface counters were cleared.
The value is the timestamp in nanoseconds relative to the Unix Epoch (Jan 1, 1970 00:00:00 UTC).
Index
Bit rate calculated on the In Octets counter.
Bit rate calculated on the Out Octets counter.
Error rate calculated on the In Octets counter.
Error rate calculated on the Out Octets counter.
The OpenFlow data path unique ID. The lower 48-bits are for a MAC address, while the upper 16-bits are implementer-defined.

OpenFlow agent failure mode. -Secure: Packets and messages destined to the controllers are dropped. Flow entries continue to expire according to their timeouts. -Standalone: Processes all packets using the OFPP_NORMAL reserved port. The switch acts as a legacy Ethernet switch or router.
The OpenFlow agent connection back off interval.
The OpenFlow agent maximum back off time.
The OpenFlow agent inactivity probe period.

Enters with DataMapper. Contains the list of connections to the Openflow main controller. The Openflow switch always connects to configured Openflow controllers. Each controller can have more than one connection, called auxiliary Openflow connections.
This is the key used internally by DataMiner to identify the table entries.

Controller auxiliary ID. Must be 0 for the main controller. One controller may have multiple auxiliary connections as specified by the Openflow protocol. Besides configuring the main controller, it is also possible to configure auxiliary connections. The main controller must have the auxiliary id set to zero. All others must have an auxiliary id different from zero.
Optional value for servicing auxiliary connections with different priorities.
The IP address of the controller.
Controller port to use.

Controller transport protocol used: TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) TLS (Transport Layer Security) Unresolvable: Enumerable value cannot be resolved to a valid transport value. N/A: value is not present.
Certificate ID is used for TLS connections. When installed, cerficates are associated with an ID. This ID specifies the certificate to use in a TLS connection.
Optionally specify the source interface for the controller connection.
When connected, indicates the connection between the switch and controller is established.
Display key.

Enters with manual parsing through polling. Contains the list of connections to the Openflow second controller. The Openflow switch always connects to configured Openflow controllers. Each controller can have more than one connection, called auxiliary Openflow connections.

Param.Name: OpenflowSecondControllerConnectionsPolledPrimaryKey
Param.Description: Primary Key (Openflow Second Controller Connections Polled)

Information.Subtext: This is the key used internally by DataMiner to identify the table entries.

Param.Name: OpenflowSecondControllerConnectionsPolledAuxiliaryId
Param.Description: Auxiliary ID (Openflow Second Controller Connections Polled)

Information.Subtext: Controller auxiliary ID. Must be 0 for the main controller. One controller may have multiple auxiliary connections as specified by the Openflow protocol. Besides configuring the main controller, it is also possible to configure auxiliary connections. The main controller must have the auxiliary id set to zero. All others must have an auxiliary id different from zero.
Optional value for servicing auxiliary connections with different priorities.

Param.Name: OpenflowSecondControllerConnectionsPolledIpAddress
Param.Description: IP Address (Openflow Second Controller Connections Polled)

Information.Subtext: The IP address of the controller.
Controller port to use.

Param.Name: OpenflowSecondControllerConnectionsPolledTransportProtocol
Param.Description: Transport Protocol (Openflow Second Controller Connections Polled)

Information.Subtext: Controller transport protocol used: TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) TLS (Transport Layer Security) Unresolvable: Enumerable value cannot be resolved to a valid discreet value. N/A: value is not present.

Param.Name: OpenflowSecondControllerConnectionsPolledCertificateId
Param.Description: Certificate ID (Openflow Second Controller Connections Polled)

Information.Subtext: Certificate ID is used for TLS connections. When installed, cerficates are associated with an ID. This ID specifies the certificate to use in a TLS connection.

Param.Name: OpenflowSecondControllerConnectionsPolledSourceInterface
Param.Description: Source Interface (Openflow Second Controller Connections Polled)

Information.Subtext: Optionally specify the source interface for the controller connection.
When connected, indicates the connection between the switch and controller is established.

Param.Name: OpenflowSecondControllerConnectionsPolledDisplayKey
Param.Description: Display Key (Openflow Second Controller Connections Polled)

Information.Subtext: Display key.
